channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Lens Blog: Palestinian Pleasures
item.description: Instead of relying on familiar tropes to capture the contemporary Palestinian experience, Tanya Habjouqa chose to focus on the pleasure and the humor rather than the suffering.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES ESTRIN
item.media:description: Boys splashed in a plastic swimming pool under an olive tree in the West Bank village of Kufr Ni'ma. Though the water supply to Israeli settlers in the West Bank is abundant and uninterrupted, many Palestinian communities there suffer from chronic water shortages. 2013.

item.title: Hundreds of Police Officers Are Reassigned in Turkey
item.description: The move is the latest development in efforts by Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey to contain a spreading corruption scandal.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY and SEBNEM ARSU

item.title: The Lede: Egyptian Bloggers Who Mobilized Support for 2011 Uprising in Jail or Under Threat
item.description: As the third anniversary of Egypt’s 2011 uprising approaches, many activists who helped mobilize support for the sit-in that drove Hosni Mubarak from power are facing extended prison terms for daring to protest the new military-backed government.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: January 7
item.description: The royal couple of Bhutan is on an official visit to India.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Another Worryingly Low Inflation Rate for the Euro Zone
item.description: The situation suggests that Europe is still flirting with deflation — an economically dysfunctional condition in which prices decline.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Charges Filed in Attack on Chinese Consulate in San Francisco
item.description: The Chinese citizen who was arrested in connection with the Jan. 1 arson attack faces federal charges of arson and damaging the property of a foreign government.
item.dc:creator: By AMY QIN
item.media:description: A San Francisco police officer stood outside the entrance to the Chinese Consulate a day after it was damaged in an arson attack.

item.title: Greek Police Hunt for Convicted Terrorist Who Disappeared on Furlough
item.description: Christodoulos Xiros, a member of the terrorist group November 17, is at large after failing to check in with the police, fueling fears of a resurgence in political violence.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: Goodyear Managers Held by French Workers Then Released
item.description: Employees at Goodyear’s plant in Amiens had kept the two directors captive for two days in a dispute over severance payments.
item.dc:creator: By LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:description: Two executives at the Goodyear factory in Amiens, France -- from right, Michel Dheilly and Bernard Glesser -- were prevented by workers from leaving the plant on Monday.

item.title: Judge Charges Spanish Princess With Tax Fraud
item.description: The corruption investigation has also ensnared the princess’s husband, who is fighting charges of fraud, tax evasion and embezzlement.
item.category: Juan Carlos I, King of Spain
item.dc:creator: By DOREEN CARVAJAL

item.title: India Ink: A Conversation With: Author Rana Dasgupta
item.description: The author spoke with India Ink about his new book, “Capital: A Portrait of Twenty-First Century Delhi,” a literary portrait of India’s capital.
item.dc:creator: By AAYUSH SONI
item.media:description: Rana Dasgupta, author of the book 'Capital: A Portrait of Twenty-First Century Delhi'.

item.title: India Ink: As Donations Pour In, Aam Aadmi Party Tries to Transform Campaign Finance
item.description: The party lists all donors’ names, both big and small, which is a considerable departure from the murky practices considered the norm in Indian politics.
item.dc:creator: By NEHA THIRANI BAGRI
item.media:description: Supporters of Aam Aadmi Party listening to Arvind Kejriwal, chief minister of Delhi, at Ramlila ground in New Delhi on Dec. 28.

item.title: Run Run Shaw, Movie Mogul Seen as Creator of Kung Fu Genre, Dies at 106
item.description: Mr. Shaw and his older brother, Run Me, were movie pioneers in Asia, producing and sometimes directing films like “Five Fingers of Death.”
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN KANDELL
item.media:description: Run Run Shaw in 1978 with his wife and daughter. Mr. Shaw and his older brother were movie pioneers in Asia, producing and sometimes directing films and owning cinema chains.

item.title: U.S. Outlines Efforts to Reach Plea With Indian Diplomat
item.description: Prosecutors have had “hours of discussion” in hopes of negotiating a plea in the case of a woman charged with visa fraud, the United States attorney’s office said.
item.dc:creator: By BENJAMIN WEISER

item.title: Rodman Leading Team of Improbable Emissaries
item.description: Dennis Rodman is the ringleader of an unlikely group headed to North Korea that has left the diplomatic corps puzzled and perhaps a little jealous over the access to Kim Jong-un.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT CACCIOLA
item.media:description: The former N.B.A. player Dennis Rodman arrived Monday in Pyongyang to celebrate the birthday of Kim Jong-un, North Korea’s leader.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Destroys 6 Tons of Ivory
item.description: Chinese authorities on Monday destroyed confiscated ivory ornaments and tusks in Dongguan, a city in the southern province of Guangdong, which is a major hub for the ivory trade.
item.category: Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species
item.dc:creator: By BETTINA WASSENER
item.media:description: Customs officers stood guard in front of illegal ivory as it was destroyed in Dongguan.

item.title: Saudis’ Grant to Lebanon Is Seen as Message to U.S.
item.description: Saudi Arabia’s $3 billion gift to the Lebanese Army was intended as much to send a message to the United States as to shift the military balance, analysts said.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: President François Hollande of France with the Saudi crown prince, Salman bin Abdulaziz al-Saud, in Riyadh last month.

item.title: Bangladesh’s Governing Party Wins Vote Amid Unrest
item.description: The Awami League won more than two-thirds of the seats in Parliament in a vote undercut by low turnout, a boycott by the main opposition party and deadly violence.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY
item.media:description: Polling officers tallied votes on Sunday in Dhaka.

item.title: U.S. and Iran Face Common Enemies in Mideast Strife
item.description: The United States and Iran are being drawn together by their mutual opposition to a movement of Sunni fighters raising Al Qaeda’s flag in Syria, Lebanon, Iraq, Afghanistan and Yemen.
item.category: Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: Tribal fighters in Ramadi on Monday. Iran offered to join the United States in sending military aid to Iraq’s Shiite government.

item.title: Germany Adds Lessons in Islam to Better Blend Its Melting Pot
item.description: Public schools for the first time are offering classes in Islam to primary school students to better integrate Germany’s large Muslim minority and to try to counter the influence of radical religious thinking.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.media:description: Timur Kumlu, left, with his first graders. “We must educate so that they develop a personality with common roots,” he said.

item.title: Bodies of 2 American Climbers Found in Argentina
item.description: Francis Keenan, 28, and Jarod Von Rueden, 22, were trying to scale Mount Aconcagua when Mr. Von Rueden sent out a distress radio signal Dec. 31.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: World Briefing | United Nations: Jordan to Renew Appeal on Syrian Refugees
item.description: The ambassador to the United Nations from Jordan said he would renew his appeal to the governing body to visit countries that shelter millions of Syrian refugees, including his own.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Africans Continue to Protest in Israel
item.description: Thousands of African asylum seekers flooded the streets of Tel Aviv for a second day on Monday to protest their treatment by the Israeli authorities.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: African asylum seekers outside the American Embassy in Tel Aviv on Monday. They were protesting their treatment and demanding recognition as refugees.

item.title: High Stakes for Sudan in the South’s Conflict
item.description: With the flow of oil and border security at risk, the longstanding rivals discussed joint patrols of South Sudan’s oil fields, among other measures.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By ISMA’IL KUSHKUSH and NICHOLAS KULISH
item.media:description: South Sudanese refugees have fled fighting to Uganda. Regional leaders worry that the crisis in South Sudan will increase the flow of refugees.

item.title: Dubai Journal: After Winning Expo, Emirate Fumes at Allies It Says Didn’t Back It
item.description: After Pakistan and Afghanistan were accused of casting their votes for other cities in the competition for the 2020 World Expo, the score-settling started.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED
item.media:description: Celebrations of the United Arab Emirates’ National Day last month and Dubai’s selection to host the 2020 World Expo.

item.title: Israeli Official Points to ‘Incitement’ by Palestinians
item.description: As Israel sought to highlight negative portrayals of Jews in Palestinian Authority media and textbooks, Palestinians dismissed the accusation as a ruse to distract from issues like borders.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
